_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1. Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.

The management and employees of New Alliance FS Inc. are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Washington fire department, Washington County LEPC, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.

The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 425 Hwy 1 & 92, Washington Iowa, is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. The storage and handling system consists of 1 30,000 gallon storage tank, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks.   Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors.

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 430,000 pounds, this includes the amount of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse tanks.


4. The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

5. Five year accident history. 

There have been 1 accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that:
- have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; or
- to our knowledge, have resul

ted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
January 2000 - A employee was filling nurse tanks when the employee removed a hose he received a burn on his leg.  Employee did not use the bleed off valve properly.  The employee was treated and released with no further injuries.  Proper NH3 procedures were instructed to employee again.  There was a minimal amount of product lost.

6. The emergency response program.

The facility has:
- a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;
- provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the Washington Fire Department and the Washington County LEPC and request that they respond to the emergency.  Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire department and LEPC.

7. Planned changes to improve safety. 

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions.  There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
